trans-unit.source: How to Tag a Virtual Machine in Azure
trans-unit.target: How to Tag a Virtual Machine in Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn about Tagging a Virtual Machine in Azure
trans-unit.target: Learn about Tagging a Virtual Machine in Azure

trans-unit.source: This article describes different ways to tag a virtual machine in Azure through the Azure Resource Manager.
trans-unit.target: This article describes different ways to tag a virtual machine in Azure through the Azure Resource Manager.

trans-unit.source: Tags are user-defined Key/Value pairs which can be placed directly on a resource or a resource group.
trans-unit.target: Tags are user-defined Key/Value pairs which can be placed directly on a resource or a resource group.

trans-unit.source: Azure currently supports up to 15 tags per resource and resource group.
trans-unit.target: Azure currently supports up to 15 tags per resource and resource group.

trans-unit.source: Tags may be placed on a resource at the time of creation or added to an existing resource.
trans-unit.target: Tags may be placed on a resource at the time of creation or added to an existing resource.

trans-unit.source: Please note, tags are supported for resources created via the Azure Resource Manager only.
trans-unit.target: Please note, tags are supported for resources created via the Azure Resource Manager only.

trans-unit.source: First, let’s look at tagging through templates.
trans-unit.target: First, let’s look at tagging through templates.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>This template</linkText><title></title> places tags on the following resources: Compute (Virtual Machine), Storage (Storage Account), and Network (Public IP Address, Virtual Network, and Network Interface).
trans-unit.target: <linkText>This template</linkText><title></title> places tags on the following resources: Compute (Virtual Machine), Storage (Storage Account), and Network (Public IP Address, Virtual Network, and Network Interface).

trans-unit.source: Click the Deploy to Azure button from the template link.
trans-unit.target: Click the Deploy to Azure button from the template link.

trans-unit.source: This will navigate to the <linkText>Azure Preview Portal</linkText><title></title> where you can deploy this template.
trans-unit.target: This will navigate to the <linkText>Azure Preview Portal</linkText><title></title> where you can deploy this template.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Simple deployment with Tags</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Simple deployment with Tags</linkText>

trans-unit.source: This template includes the following tags: Department, Application, and Created By.
trans-unit.target: This template includes the following tags: Department, Application, and Created By.

trans-unit.source: You can add/edit these tags directly in the template if you would like different tag names.
trans-unit.target: You can add/edit these tags directly in the template if you would like different tag names.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Azure tags in a template</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Azure tags in a template</linkText>

trans-unit.source: As you can see, the tags are defined as Key/Value pairs, separated by a colon (:).
trans-unit.target: As you can see, the tags are defined as Key/Value pairs, separated by a colon (:).

trans-unit.source: The tags must be defined in this format:
trans-unit.target: The tags must be defined in this format:

trans-unit.source: Save the template file after you finish editing it with the tags of your choice.
trans-unit.target: Save the template file after you finish editing it with the tags of your choice.

trans-unit.source: Next, in the Edit Parameters section, you can fill out the values for your tags.
trans-unit.target: Next, in the Edit Parameters section, you can fill out the values for your tags.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Edit Tags in Azure Portal</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Edit Tags in Azure Portal</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click Create to deploy this template with your tag values.
trans-unit.target: Click Create to deploy this template with your tag values.

trans-unit.source: After creating your resources with tags, you can view, add, and delete tags in the portal.
trans-unit.target: After creating your resources with tags, you can view, add, and delete tags in the portal.

trans-unit.source: Select the tags icon to view your tags:
trans-unit.target: Select the tags icon to view your tags:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Tags icon in Azure Portal</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Tags icon in Azure Portal</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Add a new tag through the portal by defining your own Key/Value pair, and save it.
trans-unit.target: Add a new tag through the portal by defining your own Key/Value pair, and save it.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Add new Tag in Azure Portal</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Add new Tag in Azure Portal</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Your new tag should now appear in the list of tags for your resource.
trans-unit.target: Your new tag should now appear in the list of tags for your resource.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>New Tag saved in Azure Portal</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>New Tag saved in Azure Portal</linkText>

trans-unit.source: To create, add, and delete tags through PowerShell, you first need to set up your <linkText>PowerShell environment with Azure Resource Manager</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To create, add, and delete tags through PowerShell, you first need to set up your <linkText>PowerShell environment with Azure Resource Manager</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Once you have completed the setup, you can place tags on Compute, Network, and Storage resources at creation or after the resource is created via PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: Once you have completed the setup, you can place tags on Compute, Network, and Storage resources at creation or after the resource is created via PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: This article will concentrate on viewing/editing tags placed on Virtual Machines.
trans-unit.target: This article will concentrate on viewing/editing tags placed on Virtual Machines.

trans-unit.source: First, navigate to a Virtual Machine through the Get-AzureVM cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: First, navigate to a Virtual Machine through the Get-AzureVM cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: If your Virtual Machine already contains tags, you will then see all the tags on your resource:
trans-unit.target: If your Virtual Machine already contains tags, you will then see all the tags on your resource:

trans-unit.source: If you would like to add tags through PowerShell, you can use the Set-AzureResource command.
trans-unit.target: If you would like to add tags through PowerShell, you can use the Set-AzureResource command.

trans-unit.source: Note when updating tags through PowerShell, tags are updated as a whole.
trans-unit.target: Note when updating tags through PowerShell, tags are updated as a whole.

trans-unit.source: So if you are adding one tag to a resource that already has tags, you will need to include all the tags that you want to be placed on the resource.
trans-unit.target: So if you are adding one tag to a resource that already has tags, you will need to include all the tags that you want to be placed on the resource.

trans-unit.source: Below is an example of how to add additional tags to a resource through PowerShell Cmdlets.
trans-unit.target: Below is an example of how to add additional tags to a resource through PowerShell Cmdlets.

trans-unit.source: This first cmdlet sets all of the tags placed on MyWindowsVM to the tags variable, using the Get-AzureResource and Tags function.
trans-unit.target: This first cmdlet sets all of the tags placed on MyWindowsVM to the tags variable, using the Get-AzureResource and Tags function.

trans-unit.source: The second command displays the tags for the given variable.
trans-unit.target: The second command displays the tags for the given variable.

trans-unit.source: The third command adds an additional tag to the tags variable.
trans-unit.target: The third command adds an additional tag to the tags variable.

trans-unit.source: Note the use of the += to append the new Key/Value pair to the tags list.
trans-unit.target: Note the use of the += to append the new Key/Value pair to the tags list.

trans-unit.source: The fourth command sets all of the tags defined in the tags variable to the given resource.
trans-unit.target: The fourth command sets all of the tags defined in the tags variable to the given resource.

trans-unit.source: In this case, it is MyWindowsVM.
trans-unit.target: In this case, it is MyWindowsVM.

trans-unit.source: The fifth command displays all of the tags on the resource.
trans-unit.target: The fifth command displays all of the tags on the resource.

trans-unit.source: As you can see, Location is now defined as a tag with MyLocation as the value.
trans-unit.target: As you can see, Location is now defined as a tag with MyLocation as the value.

trans-unit.source: To learn more about tagging through PowerShell, check out the <linkText>Azure Resource Cmdlets</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To learn more about tagging through PowerShell, check out the <linkText>Azure Resource Cmdlets</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Tagging is also supported for resources that are already created through the Azure CLI.
trans-unit.target: Tagging is also supported for resources that are already created through the Azure CLI.

trans-unit.source: To begin, set up your <linkText>Azure CLI environment</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To begin, set up your <linkText>Azure CLI environment</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Log in to your subscription through the Azure CLI and switch to ARM mode.
trans-unit.target: Log in to your subscription through the Azure CLI and switch to ARM mode.

trans-unit.source: You can view all properties for a given Virtual Machine, including the tags, using this command:
trans-unit.target: You can view all properties for a given Virtual Machine, including the tags, using this command:

trans-unit.source: Unlike PowerShell, if you are adding tags to a resource that already contains tags, you do not need to specify all tags (old and new) before using the azure vm set command.
trans-unit.target: Unlike PowerShell, if you are adding tags to a resource that already contains tags, you do not need to specify all tags (old and new) before using the azure vm set command.

trans-unit.source: Instead, this command allows you to append a tag to your resource.
trans-unit.target: Instead, this command allows you to append a tag to your resource.

trans-unit.source: To add a new VM tag through the Azure CLI, you can use the azure vm set command along with the tag parameter -t:
trans-unit.target: To add a new VM tag through the Azure CLI, you can use the azure vm set command along with the tag parameter -t:

trans-unit.source: To remove all tags, you can use the –T parameter in the azure vm set command.
trans-unit.target: To remove all tags, you can use the –T parameter in the azure vm set command.

trans-unit.source: Now that we have applied tags to our resources via PowerShell, Azure CLI, and the Portal, let’s take a look at the usage details to see the tags in the billing portal.
trans-unit.target: Now that we have applied tags to our resources via PowerShell, Azure CLI, and the Portal, let’s take a look at the usage details to see the tags in the billing portal.

trans-unit.source: Tags placed on Compute, Network, and Storage resources through the Azure Resource Manager will be populated in your usage details in the billing portal.
trans-unit.target: Tags placed on Compute, Network, and Storage resources through the Azure Resource Manager will be populated in your usage details in the billing portal.

trans-unit.source: Click on Download usage details to view the usage details in your subscription.
trans-unit.target: Click on Download usage details to view the usage details in your subscription.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Usage details in Azure Portal</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Usage details in Azure Portal</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Select your billing statement and the Version 2 usage details:
trans-unit.target: Select your billing statement and the Version 2 usage details:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Version 2 Preview Usage Details in Azure Portal</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Version 2 Preview Usage Details in Azure Portal</linkText>

trans-unit.source: From the usage details, you can see all of the tags in the Tags column:
trans-unit.target: From the usage details, you can see all of the tags in the Tags column:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Tags column in Azure Portal</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Tags column in Azure Portal</linkText>

trans-unit.source: By analyzing these tags along with usage, organizations will be able to gain new insights into their consumption data.
trans-unit.target: By analyzing these tags along with usage, organizations will be able to gain new insights into their consumption data.
